Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 04:04AM bourscheid wrote: Thought I posted here earlier but can't find it.  I have gone back to 2 chemos with success.  The first was xeloda which got me to NED then I later had a recurrance (after 15 months) and after Taxotere got me NED again I went back on xeloda as a maintenance.  Stayed NED for 9 months.  Recurrance again then back to Abraxane which was the first chemo I went on back in 2008.  So far so good!  Last PET scan much improved!  Liver stable with reduced activity and the mets around the heart and in the adranal gland are gone.  So, there is something to be said for trying a chemo again after having success with it.  At least you know what to expect.  :-)

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 05:45PM bourscheid wrote: I am a 5th grade teacher and was diagnosed in Aug.  I had my surgery (mastectomy) on the first day back to work for teachers and got the cancer diagnosis at that time.  I missed 2 weeks of work (one week with the students) and worked half days the first week back.  Since then I have been working full time and only miss 1/2 day for treatment and the day after to rest ((Thurs and Fri) My boss, the staff , families and especially the students have been very supportive and understanding.  I too use germ x frequently.  I also use a 10%clorox/water solution to spray the desks daily and use the lysol wipes on the door knobs, switches, computer mouse and keyboard, etc. to help keep the germs down.  So far, so good, even with colds running rampant.   Since my students are older, they have been told exactly what is going on and are wonderful about everything.  They love to see what I am going to be wearing on my head and can't even remember what I looked like with hair!  I agree with Denise, keep a positive outlook, it will make a world of difference to you and the students as well. Best of luck to you! Lori

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 02:48AM bourscheid wrote: Hi ladies!  Went for Halaven on Thursday (last of cycle 3) and lo and behold I was running a fever.  I haven't run a fever in 10 years.  Well, I have this boil on my rear and had sat in a meeting in a hard chair for 6 hours then drove 3 hours home (all that on day 5).  Not a good idea.  Boil is infected and actually got the size of a golf ball...ouch!  So, no Halaven.  Antibiotics and hot compresses.  Seems to be working though.  No fever today and feeling much better, there is great shrinkage, etc. in the "hot seat".  Have to go back on Monday for the Halaven which will really screw up my work week...the week before Spring Break.  At least my off week is during Spring Break so I can enjoy myself a little.  On a better note...I get a week at the beach compliments of Little Pink Houses of Hope!  Woohoo!  Can't wait until May 13!

I am thinking about going out on disability at the end of this school year.  Finally decided that it is time for ME to live my life how I want to and not by someone else's schedule.  Thoughts?

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2012 07:58PM bourscheid wrote: I was dx stage IV in Aug. 2008 with TNBC mets to the chest/mediastanal (sp?) nodes throughout as well as numerous lesions in the liver...was given NO expiration date...onc DID tell me to get my affairs in order NOT because I had a short time but because everyone who has kids should have this taken care of.  Then he proceeded to tell me that we were treating this as a chronic disease to keep under control and have the best quality of life possible on chemo.  That was 4 years ago, 2 times NED on my 3rd recurrance and working my way toward NED again. (those pesky liver mets keep hanging in there but they are shrinking - only 2 right not).  Have been on some form of chemo the whole time, reduced dosages while NED for maintenance (agressive TNBC).  Live is good!  Just retired from teaching (taught the last 4 years in tx and took my first real sick day this year due to tx.)  Retired to enjoy life for a while!

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 04:44PM bourscheid wrote:   Just got back from the onc and got the results of the latest PET scan...Great news ladies! As you know, the original diagnosis showed cancer had spread in most if not all the nodes of the chest and supraclavical (collar bone) area as well as multiple (at least 7) lesions (tumors) in the liver - two of which were 8cm or larger. There was also some plural effusion and possible spinal lesions.  Well... all of the cancer is GONE except for one small (2 cm) area in the liver!!!!!  We are overjoyed (including the onc)!  Dr. M said the response was way better than he had dared to hope for!   I will now go for two more cycles of abraxane/avastin (6 tx) the first of which I had today.  After that we will rescan and decide on what if any further treatment is needed. Have a great afternoon! Lori

Posts.Content: bourscheid wrote: Need my Stage IV sisters prayers and good thoughts right now!  My husband had his 6 month checkup at the doc last week and during his exam the doc found a nodule on the prostrate.  Went to a urologist yesterday who is getting him set up for a biopsy...1 in 3 chance it could be cancer!  I handled everything so well when it was me facing this and have adjusted to stage IV (celebrated 4 years on Aug. 18).  I am NOT handling this well for my hubby.  Now I understand his fear for me.   He is so active and healthy and strong.  He works out at the gym every other day and hikes on the Appalachian Trail every available weekend he can (usually for 2 or 3 days at a time).   He doesn't want me to say anything to the kids (who are 19 and 22) until the time of the biopsy and doesn't want to say anything to anyone else until he knows for sure what he is dealing with.  This is hard to me to do because I usually take strength from my family and friends when dealing with stressful situations.  So ladies, I am turning to you for support.   Suggestions?  Thoughts? Hugs and blessings! Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2008 01:30PM bourscheid wrote: Hi all!  I'm Lori and I start chemo on Oct. 2.  (Dose Dense AC 4x then T 4x every 2 weeks)  Had my port put in on Monday.  Tues felt like shoulder hit with sledgehammer.  Much better today (only a tack hammer)  Also had MRI and Muga on Monday right after port insertion so I think that's why it was so sore.  I did work yesterday though! I teach 5th grade and hate having to take so much time off.  Have PET/CT scan today.  Have to drive 2 hrs on windy mountain road to get there (which my shoulder is not looking forward to) but on the upside I get to see my son at school (He goes to Western Caroline University) before my test.  I think having all these tests has made me more nervous than having mastectomy!  Going to order a wig or two from  tlc this week.  No local wig shops here in the mountains of Western North Carolina.  Will have my stylist help with it when it comes. I have two kids, daughter 15 and son 18 in first year of college.  My hubby has been great but seems much more upset by all this than I am.  Any suggestions for helping him?  I also feel great even after modified radical mastectomy.  I only took 2 weeks off after surgery then back to teaching!  I do have to say that having the support of friends and church members has helped more than I ever thought (other than kids and hubby my family all live far away even though we talk frequently).   Keep thinking positive!  We'll get through this together!

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 06:22PM bourscheid wrote: Nancy from MI:  Unless it is too stressful on you physically...let the friends help out with the benefit and count the blessings.  It can feel a little funny having the attention on you but you can also use this as an example to others.  Show your strength and a positive attitude but also accept help when it comes.  That's the lesson I've learned through out this bumpy journey. I was never one to accept help before ...always thought it was a sign of weakness.  I learned it is NOT weakness but just being human.  Torchsong put it very well in her post! Yesterday the high school latin club presented me with a huge gift basket of goodies (lotions, candles, pink crocs with fuzzy insides, jelly bellys and tea and potpourri) that the 5 students in the club contributed.  It came with a beautiful card that they all wrote a message in and it was very uplifting.  These are all former 5th graders of mine except for one young man so it was really neat to see that I may have made a difference in some young lives.  As a teacher, we often don't get to see the influence we have had on our students.  I still am amazed at how many of my former students have been checking up on me throughout my cancer fight.  I guess I must have done something right somewhere along the way!

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 11:09AM bourscheid wrote: Unique - I have lots of clear mucus as well draining and find myself clearing my throat a lot.  Remember, we probably don't have nose hairs keeping all the junk out so I'd keep on top of it.  If it doesn't go away or gets worse over the next couple days, I'd make a call to the onc. ladies - check with the onc about whether to take tylenol or motrin.  My onc told me NO TYLENOL due to liver mets (it's processed through the liver and it's already working hard enough to process the chemo) but that Motrin or Aleve were okay as they're processed through the kidneys. Cheryl - how are  you doing today?  Any effects? Good luck tomorrow Fammy!  Tomorrow is #6 for me and I'm also meeting with the onc for the first time since treatment started (been seeing the PA each visit).  I'm a little nervous.  Take care and hope everyone is having a good week! Lori

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 09:20AM bourscheid wrote: Linda Great idea to use up that flexible spending!   There is a great list pinned near the top of: Forum: Chemotherapy - Before, During and After.  It has an extensive list of items for chemo.  My top ones:  Biotene mouthwash; immodium and senekot (could go either way); several soft yet cheap toothbrushes (you want to throw them away frequently); baby wipes or tucks pads; thermometer (you'll want your own); lots of hand sanitizer and  lysol or clorox wipes; tylenol or motrin (ask your onc which one you can take - different types of bc need different pain relievers); claritin (for neulasta bone pain).  There's more on the list.  Check it out.  I printed it out and took it with me to the drug store.  Good luck and keep us up to date! Lori

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 06:38PM bourscheid wrote: Treatment went well after trouble getting my port to bleed for them (7 syringes of heparan and saline and an IV bag of saline later it worked.  It probably moved up against the blood vessel wall and created a suction that had to be broken.  Fluid would go in but blood wouldn't come out.) all is well now.  Blood counts were still good (wbc 5.6).  My hair is officially growing back and the nurses and onc couldn't believe it.  They said it was really new hair and was filling in nicely.  It doesn't usually do that while on abraxane.  No more tx until Jan 8!  Wahoo! Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 07:44PM bourscheid wrote: TX #3 down.  So far so good.  I even drove myself.  My mom came with me and kept me company as this was my longer treatment (3 1/2) and it was nice.  She's here for 2 weeks from Florida to "take care of me".  I've been enjoying being spoiled.  Today when I got to work, not only did my class have the "We love you Mrs. Bourscheid" shirts on but every single faculty and staff member did as well (male and female).  It was so uplifting!  And yes, I did cry.  I wore my shirt (and my mom wore the one they bought for her) to chemo today and the nurse cried too! Next week I get a week off before my second cycle of 3 treatments. I'm looking forward to that!  I, too, feel a crash on Saturdays.  I usually feel like I could just lay my head down and snooze.  Sometimes achy too.  The nurse says it's a combination of coming off the steroids and the sleepiness from the anti nausea meds (I'm on zofran and compazine).  It's "doable" though.  I'd rather have that than the nausea. bluedasher and kathimdgd:  I understand the feelings you are having.  All those tests and waiting for results and the anticipation of the chemo.  That was actually my roughest weeks.  I'm not good at waiting.  Give me some action!  Take heart, it will go by quickly!  I can't believe I've done three already!  Dee811:  congratulations on the great scan results!  Hooray!  Hope you can combat the fatigue.  Drink a lot! I always feel more tired on the days I don't drink at least 2 quarts of liquid.  I've gotten the restless leg body feeling too.  Had to keep getting up and down. I just had to ride it out.  Didn't even think to ask about it as I get restless legs a lot.  It was strange feeling it all over though.  I'm going to contact the cleaning for a reason group.  They probably don't have service out in the boonies but I want to let them know what a great idea that is!   Love to all!  Take care ladies! Lori

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 05:51PM bourscheid wrote: Here's the Lori update.  They had  Pink Day at Hiwassee Dam School for me!  There are about 300 students in my little PK - 12 school.  My daughter said she's never seen so much pink and they sent me a picture.  I'll try to figure out how to attach it next time. What an amazing outpouring of love and support!  They all work pink today when I went for my first chemo.  Speaking of the chemo...well the rug was kinda pulled out from under us when we got to the cancer center this morning.  After a clear MRI of the brain and good muga scan, the PET scan was bad news.  The cancer has already spread: a lesion on the liver, multiple lymph nodes in the area under the collarbone and sternum are "active"; and possibly 2 areas on the spine.  I'll have a bone scan next friday (10/9) to confirm this possiblity.  That said, the chemo drugs have been changed to address these new issues.  I am now taking Abraxane and Avastin.  I will have chemo once a week for 3 weeks then two weeks rest then another cycle of once a week for 3 weeks.  After that there will be another PET scan to confirm that the chemo is effective.  If it is not working as fast as hoped then another drug (5fu) will be added.  The doc said that while he cannot say I can be "cured" now, I am definitely treatable.  The fact that I am presenting no symptoms is encouraging and makes him hopeful that this course of treatment will be effective in arresting and killing the cancer cells. He also said that though this is a more aggressive treatment (One of the drugs is a biological) the SE's may be milder than the AC-T.  I am still feeling well after chemo today (almost 4 hours out and hungry) and will stay home tomorrow and over the weekend to rest.  I will continue to work on M-W and Thurs am as long as I am feeling well.  Staying home would make me crazy.  :-)   I am still feeling positive that I can beat this beast!     Love you all! Lori

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 10:29AM bourscheid wrote: Kristi:  bring something to snack on (pb crackers, hard candy, sandwich depending on the time) as nibbling can also help keep the nausea at bay and bring drinks with you to sip on during the infusion (I usually go through at least two bottles of water or ginger ale) and keep drinking after the infusion as well for several days to flush the chemo out of your system.  Good luck to you! Deb:  so sorry you aren't feeling well.  You should be through the worst of it.  I find that when I can stop taking the anti-nausea meds my energy starts to return (especially the compazine as it makes me very sleepy).  Try to take short walks (even if only for 5 min. at a time) as it does help to move around a bit.  And don't ever apologize for whining...that's what we're here for!  Sometimes you ladies are the only ones I feel I can whine to because I know  you will understand and also not panic that something is going wrong (dh panics easily about any SE).  Tomorrow is #5 for me so today I hydrate, hydrate, hydrate (guess I'd better go dump my coffee and switch to water now ).  I had so much energy and felt better yesterday than I have since my diagnosis in Aug.  I even went out and played ball with my class - boy are my arms sore today - especially on the port side!  Then I went for a walk while they were in band and learned just how out of shape I am - only made it about 2/3 of a mile before I had to quit.  Plan on walking again today at the same time - maybe I can do a mile today - but no ball for me! Has anyone's hair stopped falling out?  I think all my brown hair fell out and the gray just keeps growing!  Of course it's mostly around the sides and back and the top is practically bald - kind of reminds me of how my grandfather used to look!    I also still have to shave the pits and legs - when is the hair I want to lose going to go? Have a great day ladies! Lori

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 12:01PM bourscheid wrote: Hi all!  Feeling much more energetic today for some reason (I usually crash on Sat.) but since I haven't had nausea, I cut down to just zofran and skipped compazine so maybe that's why.  I'll probably crash this afternoon though. Kathi - I've had to let lots of kids know about my hair (i teach elem school) and I just kind of let them take the lead.  Some want to see and others don't.  My kids in my class all want to see on a regular basis so I just pop off my hat for them.  I would talk to the mom and let her prepare them ahead of time as to why you are losing your hair (or get her permission to talk to them about it ) so that she and/or you can answer questions.  AFter the first time, the novelty is gone for the kids though.  My class said the other day...We don't even remember what you looked like with hair.  You don't have to wear a hat or wig if you don't want to.  I will though for the littler kids (plus my head gets cold!). Have a great day everyone! Lori

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 06:06PM bourscheid wrote: Cheryl:  I don't know if this helps but I am also stage IV and triple-neg.  I am taking abraxane with avastin and the side effects have been very minimal.  I have been tired on day 2 and 3 but nothing an afternoon nap doesn't help with(I have had 5 treatments already); my hair has thinned a lot (almost gone except for the gray ); on the first two treatments I had some flushing of my face and chest bot not with the last three; some hoarsness and bloody nose when I blow it occasionally (both of these are from the avastin I think).  I am given aloxi and zofran before treatment through the IV and then take compazone and zofran post treatment to keep any nausea at bay (I've not even had a hint of it).  They also have me taking 100mg daily of vitamin B6 to prevent neuropathy and so far I've not even had any tingling of the hands and feet. I understand your worry and I don't know much about herceptin and carboplatin but from the abraxane viewpoint you're going to be fine.  The other ladies are right - the side effects are much more easily managed and you need to let your onc know your concerns as well as any effects you have.  Keep us posted and let us know what we can do to help you get through this! Unique:  You are an amazing woman!  Thank you so much for keeping tabs on all of us ladies!  I appreciate your insight so much! A little funny:  just when things were going great...I had to order bifocals today!  Went to order contacts and needed an exam.  Doc was concerned about me wearing contacts during chemo as some chemo is very drying to eyes.  Well...I was more worried about having to not wear contacts than I was about losing my hair...how's that for vain!  Luckily, I can still wear contacts during the day but had to order bifocals for days when my eyes are too dry and for the evenings...guess I'm older than I thought.  A good thing...when I let her know I had mets to the liver and lymph nodes she checked my eyes to make sure there was no evidence of cancer there (BC can spread to the eyes) and they were in excellent shape with no evidence of any problems whatsoever!  Now... if only my onc can tell me that things are improving with the liver and nodes I'll be so happy!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2008 06:51PM bourscheid wrote: Here's the update after the conclusion of two rounds (6 treatments) of chemo:   Just finished treatment #6 today.  Still feeling very good!  Only a couple days of being tired after each treatment. Met with the oncologist (Dr. Manfredi) today and he was very pleased with how I am tolerating the chemo.  He said the blood work is all good and in the normal ranges and my body is staying strong.  He was pleased.  My question for him was "Is it okay to be feeling this good?"  He laughed and said yes!  The treatment they have me on (abraxane/avastin) is well tolerated and allows for a very good quality of life while still attacking the cancer strongly.  He was also pleased to see I was still working and able to keep my white blood counts in the normal range. He was worried at first about me being around so many kids all day but now he says keep on doing what I'm doing!     The new schedule for me is as follows:   One more cycle (three treatments 11/26, 12/4; and 12/11) of chemo; then a break between Dec. 11 and Jan 8!  During the break I will have a PET/CT scan (Dec. 29) to see how well the chemo is working.  I have to be off of chemo for at least two weeks before a PET/CT can be done. I'm looking forward to having that long chemo break during the Christmas holiday!  I will then meet with the Dr. on Jan. 8 to discuss the results of the scans and plan the next phase of treatment.  I'm scheduled for another chemo that day as well to start the 4th cycle.  Please keep the prayers coming that I remain strong and that the chemo is working to rid my body of this cancer.    Love to all! Lori (Bourscheid)

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 09:59AM bourscheid wrote: My son is a freshman in college.  When I got my abnormal mammo results it was only a couple days until I had to drop him off at school.  My surgery was scheduled for the next day after I dropped him off.  I told him about it right away and then when I dropped him off I also let the RD and RA know what was going on so if I needed to tell him bad news he would have a support system.  Well, the news was very bad (stage IV - spread to nodes and liver).  My husband called and told him right after surgery and he handled it very well.  I hated to have to put that shadow on his first week at college ( he is not a very mature 18 year old at times) but he did well with it.  His new friends rallied around him and helped him deal with it.  We also kept in close contact via phone, texting and e-mail.  He was able to come home after about 2 weeks at school for a weekend so it helped him to actually see that I was going to be okay. I agree with others, only you know your daughter.  My son did tell me that if I had kept it from him he would have been very angry and hurt. Hope this helps. Hugs and blessings! Lori

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2013 08:35AM bourscheid wrote: Thanks everyone!  After being on a chemo holiday for 5 months, I had forgotten what it is like...I remember now! When I went to bed last night I woke up an hour later with a war raging in my body!  Felt like I was being run over repeatedly in my midsection by a steam roller while the armies were battling in my liver!  Crazy feeling...finally resorted to pain meds and it got much better and I was able to get some sleep.  Still achy and have a nagging headache today.   Now if I could only figure out which drug was doing what...I had Doxil and Faslodex for the first time yesterday along with my Xgeva shot.  Oh well...as long as it does the job I will take it!  No nausea and no need for antinausea meds and steroids!  I'll take it! Hugs and blessings! Lori
Posts.Title: I am a changed woman! bourscheid Cafelovr

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 07:22PM bourscheid wrote: When I was first dx in Aug. 08 it was found that the cancer had already spread to lymph nodes and the liver (8 + lesions).  Started Abraxane/Avastin in Oct. 08 and by Dec. 08 all cancer was gone except one lesion in the liver which had shrunk significantly.  Switched to xeloda to get rid of that one bugger.  I was very pleased with the response to abraxane/avastin and would highly recommend it to anyone.  Yes, hair was gone and I was tired, fingers and toes tingled but I never got sick and continued to teach 5th grade full time.  Am currently in complete remission since June 09!   Good luck to you!  Hugs and blessings! Lori

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 07:30PM bourscheid wrote: First, you have to do what you feel is best for YOU.   I, too, am a teacher (for 26 years)  and have been Stage IV since diagnosis and  teaching full time on chemo since Oct. 2008.  It keep me going (even my onc says so).  There are some tough days but the kids help get you through it.  They are very understanding and compassionate.  I taught through abraxane/avastin and then xeloda then was NED for 15 months; had a recurrance in Sept. 2010 and taught through taxotere/carboplatin and am NED again since March 2011.  Back on Xeloda for maintenance in April 2011 and continuing on that indefinitely.  It can be done!   I have a very supportive administration and faculty, understanding parents of my students, and have been very honest and forthcoming with everything concerning my health.   Feel free to PM me if you have any questions!  Hugs and blessings! Lori
